terminologie_extrait.definition: blockers who attack the wide corners and opponent's elbow with nearly every shot.

causes_communes: aggressive blockers should attack the wide corners and opponent's elbow with nearly every shot
steady blockers are just that, focusing mostly on wide angles
change-of-pace blockers want to throw off the opponent's rhythm

debutant.description: Block aggressively to the wide corners and opponent's elbow.
Focus on wide angles, especially if an angled block can be attacked right back at a wide angle.
Mix in aggressive and dead blocks to throw off the opponent's rhythm.

intermediaire.description: Use sidespin to change the pace and give the opponent difficulty.

avance.description: Learn to tilt the racket tip back so as to angle your forehand block down the line, and watch the awkward returns of your opponent!

exercices_complementaires.description: Practice blocking aggressively to the wide corners and opponent's elbow, focusing on pressure and pace.
Focus on steady blocking to the wide angles, especially if an angled block can be attacked right back at a wide angle.
Practice mixing in aggressive and dead blocks to throw off the opponent's rhythm.

metriques_progression.description: Increase pace and pressure on the opponent to force errors or weak returns.
Focus on angling and deepening blocks to reduce the opponent's options.

erreurs_a_eviter.nom: lack of a forehand down-the-line block
erreurs_a_eviter.description: Develop a forehand down-the-line block to throw off opponents who expect crosscourt blocks.
Don't rely solely on quick, steady blocking; develop an attack or loop-kill for when you get a weak ball.
